explanation:
Correct calculation: Number of squares (8) compared to circles (5) gives 8:5.

Student's incorrect calculation: 8 (squares) to 8+5=13 (total shapes), resulting in 8:13.

The student treated the ratio as a comparison of squares to the total number of shapes instead of squares to circles. This occurred because they misinterpreted the ratio's purpose, incorrectly incorporating the total (13) rather than the second distinct quantity (5).

This aligns with mixing up the "part" (circles) with the "total" (shapes combined). The error is distinct from part-to-whole assumptions (which would still require the ratio to be 8:13 only if explicitly requesting squares-to-total, which the question did not). It also differs from fraction-to-ratio conversion errors, as no fraction was referenced in the problem.

The misconception directly caused the student to sum quantities that should remain separate in a part-to-part ratio.
